diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including psychosis (neuropsychiatric SLE), acute pericarditis, atrophic scarring (from chronic cutaneous lupus), synovitis, and proteinuria (as part of lupus nephritis).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily known for causing joint problems, rheumatoid arthritis can lead to pericarditis and proteinuria (secondary to amyloidosis or renal involvement). Synovitis is a hallmark of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that can cause proteinuria (renal involvement), acute pericarditis, and less commonly, neurological manifestations that might present as psychosis. Skin involvement might manifest as atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD features symptoms of several connective tissue diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus. It can present with proteinuria, synovitis, and potentially acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Schizophrenia
diagnoses.rationale: Schizophrenia is primarily a psychiatric diagnosis characterized by psychosis. While rare, in advanced stages of untreated disease, the stress might contribute indirectly to systemic symptoms such as acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting the heart valves, infectious endocarditis can have wide-ranging effects, including renal involvement (proteinuria) and rare complications leading to acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's disease is a vasculitis that can present with a broad range of symptoms, including possibly psychosis, skin manifestations (such as atrophic scarring), and less commonly, acute pericarditis or joint involvement (synovitis).

diagnoses.name: Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Following a streptococcal infection, this condition can cause proteinuria due to renal involvement. Acute rheumatic fever, a related condition, can lead to pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Different forms of vasculitis such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis) can involve renal (proteinuria), cardiac (acute pericarditis), and joint (synovitis) manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: Tuberculosis can have wide-reaching systemic effects, including renal involvement (proteinuria), pericarditis, and potential skin manifestations. Psychiatric symptoms like psychosis could arise as a result of systemic illness or related stresses.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its tissues, can manifest with a wide array of symptoms including proteinuria, acute pericarditis, delirium, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: A microbial infection of the heart valves causing systemic effects and can lead to acute pericarditis, delirium, and pericardial effusion as complications.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by the accumulation of waste products in the blood due to renal failure, can lead to proteinuria, delirium, and pericardial conditions including pericarditis and effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop after an infection with Streptococcus bacteria and may cause acute pericarditis, along with other complications.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases causing hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can also affect internal organs, potentially leading to proteinuria, delirium, acute pericarditis, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium most commonly due to a viral infection, which can result in pericardial effusion and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, potentially affecting the pericardium (pericardial tuberculosis) which may lead to acute pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Various renal disorders can result in proteinuria. Advanced stages of kidney diseases can cause fluid overload, leading to pericardial effusion, and associated complications may contribute to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.description: Specific types of cancer or metastasis to the pericardium might cause pericardial effusion and acute pericarditis. Some cancers can also cause renal impairment, leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A condition in which substances called amyloids build up in the organs, amyloidosis can affect the heart leading to pericardial effusion and involve the kidneys causing proteinuria.

diagnoses: Tick-borne diseases (e.g., Lyme disease, Rocky Mountain spotted fever)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as discoid rash, arthropathy, alopecia, and autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for causing synovitis and arthropathy, it can sometimes present with systemic features that might mimic other autoimmune conditions.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects moisture-producing glands but can have systemic manifestations including arthropathy and has been associated with autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Discoid Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: A form of lupus that primarily affects the skin, causing a discoid rash, but can sometimes present with systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: Features symptoms of various autoimmune diseases including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, and can present with synovitis, arthropathy, and alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinct skin rash, potentially presenting with features overlapping those of autoimmune conditions.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, it might show symptoms of arthropathy and a rash, although not typically a discoid rash.

diagnoses.name: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune thyroid disorder that could present with alopecia and might have associated autoimmune hemolysis as part of a broader autoimmune syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Profundus
diagnoses.rationale: A rare form of chronic cutaneous lupus presenting with deep, painful nodules and might share systemic features seen in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: While this is a specific diagnosis related to autoimmune hemolysis, patients can sometimes have concurrent autoimmune syndromes manifesting with the listed symptoms.

diagnoses: Chronic Kidney Disease due to Glomerulonephritis

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disease can lead to neuropathies, increase the risk of miscarriage, and is associated with an increased risk of aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, Vascular Type
diagnoses.reason: A genetic disorder that can cause aneurysms, and its associated complications could lead to vomiting. The disorder's impact on the body's connective tissues could theoretically affect pregnancy outcomes.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reason: Inflammation of blood vessels, which can cause neuropathies due to affected blood flow, lead to aneurysms, and potentially cause systemic symptoms such as vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune condition that can cause systemic vascular inflammation, leading to symptoms such as aneurysms and neuropathies. Although less direct, systemic inflammation could also affect pregnancy outcomes and gastrointestinal health.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: A connective tissue disorder which can lead to aneurysms, especially in the aorta. While less directly related to the other symptoms, the systemic nature of this connective tissue disorder could potentially impact them.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.reason: This condition is a rare form of vasculitis that can cause aneurysms and neuropathies due to inflammation of the arteries, which might indirectly lead to other systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Now known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this condition includes vasculitis that can lead to neuropathies and possibly aneurysms. The systemic nature of the disease could impact various bodily systems.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disorder causing dry eyes and mouth, and can also cause peripheral neuropathy. Systemic features of the disease could plausibly lead to other complications although direct connections to miscarriage, vomiting, and aneurysms are less clear.

diagnoses.name: Hughes Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Also known as Antiphospholipid Syndrome, it increases the risk of miscarriages and can cause vascular problems including aneurysms. There's a potential indirect link to neuropathies via vascular issues.

diagnoses.name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
diagnoses.reason: This rare condition affects artery walls and can lead to aneurysms, renal artery stenosis, and high blood pressure, potentially causing complications that overlap with the symptoms listed, including neuropathic symptoms.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) - including Ulcerative Colitis

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by non-restorative sleep and can have various secondary symptoms that might relate to the patient's condition.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions like lupus can cause thrombocytopenia, periodontal disease through secondary infections, and have been associated with sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A disorder that can lead to thromboembolic disease and might indirectly contribute to other symptoms due to poor overall health.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin and Mineral Deficiencies
diagnoses.rationale: Deficiencies, especially in vitamin B12, can cause tinnitus and thrombocytopenia, and indirectly contribute to non-restorative sleep.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Might cause thromboembolic events, contribute to non-restorative sleep through alterations in body chemistry, and has been linked with periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.rationale: Directly causes non-restorative sleep and has been associated with an increased risk of thromboembolic disease.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Can lead to periodontal disease, contribute to thromboembolic events, and affect sleep quality.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause thrombocytopenia and is associated with cryoglobulinemia, which might lead to thromboembolic disease.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Can lead to fatigue and non-restorative sleep, and has been linked with higher cholesterol levels, potentially increasing the risk of thromboembolic events.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions such as periodontal disease can lead to systemic inflammation, contributing indirectly to conditions like thromboembolic disease and affecting sleep quality.

diagnoses: Chronic stress or severe emotional distress
Infections that affect multiple body systems
Sensorineural hearing loss due to systemic disease
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) - related to chemical sensitivities
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Intestinal infections (e.g., viral or bacterial gastroenteritis)
Toxic ingestion (such as from certain plants, chemicals, or heavy metals)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, weakness, especially on one side of the body, severe headache, confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by intense pain accompanied by nausea, sensitivity to light, and sound. Aura symptoms such as scintillating scotoma can precede or accompany the headache. These can include visual disturbances, like flashes of light, and changes in speech or sensation, such as numbness or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms mimic those of a full stroke but typically resolve within minutes to hours and may include weakness, numbness, aphasia, and vision changes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is a disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms can include numbness, weakness, problems with coordination and balance, and issues with speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, weakness or numbness in parts of the body, and speech disturbances such as aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Specific forms of epilepsy may present with sensory disturbances, including numbness or prickling sensations, before a seizure.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck. In severe cases, symptoms may escalate to confusion, seizures, and difficulties with coordination and speech.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre Syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body. In its most severe form, it's a medical emergency.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: A subarachnoid hemorrhage is bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering the brain, known as the subarachnoid space. It's often caused by the bursting of a weakened blood vessel. Symptoms include a sudden, severe headache, numbness, weakness, vision problems, seizures, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: Temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis) is an inflammation of the blood vessels that supply blood to the head and brain. Symptoms can include headaches, jaw pain, vision disturbances, and stroke-like symptoms (such as weakness and speech difficulties) in severe cases. Immediate treatment is critical to prevent permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Tension-type headache
diagnoses.details: A common type of headache characterized by a constant pressure or ache around the head, especially at the temples or back of the head and neck.

diagnoses.name: Chronic daily headaches
diagnoses.details: Refers to having headaches on 15 days or more a month for longer than three months.

diagnoses.name: Medication overuse headache
diagnoses.details: Headache occurring 15 or more days a month in a patient with a pre-existing headache disorder and develops as a consequence of regular overuse of acute or symptomatic headache medication.

diagnoses.name: Anaemia
diagnoses.details: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, which might cause weakness and tiredness among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.details: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, leading to symptoms like fatigue, weight gain, and possibly contributing to headache.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.details: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. It might be associated with tinnitus and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic neuroma
diagnoses.details: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that runs from your brain to your inner ear, can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.details: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include fatigue, numbness, weakness, and in some cases, headache.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.details: Any intracranial tumor caused by abnormal and uncontrolled cell division, either in the brain or the central spinal canal. Depending on its location, it might cause headache, weakness, and other neurological symptoms including tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In some cases, migraines are preceded by sensory disturbances called auras, which can include scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A subtype of migraine that involves visual disturbances or aura, such as scintillation, flashes of light, or blind spots, before the onset of the actual headache.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, tinnitus (ringing in the ears), and progressive hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by high pressure in the spaces around the brain and spinal cord, causing headaches, vision problems, and in some cases, tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause headaches, seizures, weakness, or cognitive changes depending on its location and size.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord, leading to weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and in some cases, visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells, leading to fatigue, weakness, and in some cases, headaches.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure, which can lead to headaches, and in severe cases, contribute to conditions causing tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the temporal arteries, which can cause headaches, jaw pain, vision problems, and sometimes tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the nerve that connects the ear to the brain, leading to hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can cause hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, and is associated with skin lesions which could manifest as telangiectasias or nasal ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily associated with joint issues, it can cause systemic effects including hemolytic anemia and can lead to skin manifestations such as telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.rationale: This condition is known for causing nasal or oral ulcers and can also lead to blood disorders including leukopenia. Vasculitis can cause skin changes, including potentially telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting exocrine glands, it can cause leukopenia and has been associated with vasculitis, which might lead to skin changes including telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This is a vasculitis disorder known for oral and possibly nasal ulcers. It can also cause skin lesions and, in rare cases, hematological manifestations like hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This condition, which overlaps several autoimmune disorders, can cause a wide range of symptoms including hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, and skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: Associated with skin changes, including telangiectasias. Systemic scleroderma can affect the blood, leading to anemia and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.rationale: A genetic disorder characterized by telangiectasias. It doesn't directly cause hemolytic anemia or leukopenia but could be considered given the prominence of telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily involves platelets but can be confused with conditions causing leukopenia and anemia. Blood vessel abnormalities could theoretically contribute to skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder can cause blood clots that lead to hemolytic anemia. It might present with vasculitis, potentially causing skin lesions or other related symptoms.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr virus or HIV)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Mental health disorders secondary to systemic illness or medication side effects
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura)
